I could not find a good test that will fail the first implementation and succeed this implementation. I have the feeling that the first implementation is more permissive because it was relying on a deep equal as well as trusted the equal method of the objects being tested for mutations.

An example of a test would be to create a new type which only returns true if its the same instance otherwise returns false and also a coder which returns a structural value which is a new type that says its equal as long as the other object is of the same type.
rebased on master

I did some analysis on what goes wrong writing to a Parquet file.
First I added the option present in the Parquet write to overwrite the output.
That yielded a new insight into what goes wrong.
It turns out that the current implementation uses the same filename for each parallel instance writing the data. That is why the test fails with file already exists.

With the overwrite option you therfor get a different error that effectively says "bad file" which is simply caused by the threads obliterating the data written by the others.

My current assessment is that the "numShards and "shardNameTemplate" construct (as seen in TextIO) needs to be added here as well to make it work.

*"Be better than the day before!" -*
*+1 404 751 8024*
I did the check that provided separator does not self-overlaps. PTAL
@bjchambers can you please take a look at my answers to your comments?

I did a local attempt to use FileBasedSink to make this work because that already has the notion of numShards. 
As far as I can tell this won't work for Parquet because I think that this assumes a header, set of records and a footer. The desired number of shards is later on realized by rewriting to the desired number of files after everything has been completed.
If I am right here then formats like Parquet and Orc (i.e. blocks of mangled records with advanced stats in headers and footers) will be very hard to created in a controlled way in Beam.

Only comment I probably have is that I would prefer the "core" functionality on top, and helper methods and classes at the bottom, so that reading through the file starts from "what it does".
So I guess I'd put `groupAlsoByWindow` first, followed by order of usage (the first helper called comes after and so on..).
But that might be just me  

Think abut it, but other than that LGTM.

I was also involved in this.
This is what I thought last I checked the Spark1.x/2.x difference:
  
1. We keep supporting only the RDD API, "Structured Streaming" does not provide a stateful operator that scans the entire state (last I checked..).
2. There was an idea to dynamically switch between the `Iterator`s and `Iterable`s since this was the only compile-time difference I noticed. If we can do this we can actually support both with minimal duplication.
